title: How do people not understand Nemesis Draft?
body:
I mean the concept is incredibly simple, yet I've had 4 games in a row today where one of the following has happened:

- Team: "ban bad champions, the other team picks for us and vice versa"
- Captain: *bans Nidalee, Yasuo, and Zed*


- Me: "does everyone understand how this mode works?"
- Summoner X: "lol nope, don't care either"


- Summoner X: "wait, why did my opponent get Jinx after I picked her? I wanted to play Jinx, wtf is going on!?!?"

What is so hard to understand about this game mode? It's essentially just the reverse of regular draft. Are people REALLY too lazy to read the small 2-line blurb on the home menu explaining what the mode is about? Why would you even THINK about doing something before you have a clear idea of what it will entail? Or is example #2 correct and people simply don't care? What the hell is wrong with you all? I swear, common sense is getting less and less common these days......

I see what Riot was trying to do with this mode, but it's kinda just causing conflict. I've lost every Nemesis Draft game I've played so far because people don't know what they're doing, then want to throw blame around. 

One game, I tried telling my team "Don't give them supports or tanks, you think they're weak but they're strong in this mode", and it was just a friendly suggestion, but the team proceeded on to do what I told them not to. We lost that game (obviously, since I said I've yet to win one), and they blamed ME for not telling them. Wait, I did tell them. But according to them I "Didn't say it like I meant it."

After Snowdown and Poro Toss, which I loved to bits, there's this that the only real "difference" in it is the champion select. After that, it's just like a normal game full of troll picks. And we see that enough already in ranked.

Think of this as Riot's way of teaching players how to communicate. If you are losing this mode perhaps your communication needs improvement. Their is no such thing as troll picks, only players who label people as trolls because they are unhappy with the outcomes. A team full of "Trolls" can win if they communicate, so are they really "Trolls?"

I believe that the reason to the "Nemesis Draft" misunderstanding is all due to misreading, or not choosing to read at all.
I do believe that people should pay a little more attention to the details, but at the same time, you cannot expect everyone to know how to play a new game that came out super recently.

In fact, one of the main reasons everyone knows how to even PLAY league of legends, is due to trial and error, testing and seeing the outcome.
That is one of the reasons why people are actually GOOD at league of legends, is it not? :)

So I have been playing some of this game mode and it seems extremely lackluster. The idea was solid, but handing people champs they don't own and flounder with in any given lane, in this community, usually ends up in the most Sodium Chloride inducing toxic games I have ever had the displeasure of crawling through. The games take a long time because nobody can decide who to give, the champs have been quite unknown, and everything feels like it is in slow motion for ninety percent of the team with the other ten percent being those that actually know the champ they got. I know the point is to try to screw the team to the wall with bad picks, but on this scale, it just isn't fun. The better choice would have been The Twisted Treeline for this mode in my opinion because it would have allowed for people to break up into groups they thought could work together while also bringing the scale and average time of the game down. Adding in the fact that the items are slightly different and many people don't play support on that map would have intensified the game and not made some people feel way underpowered while some feel like they can do it all. Good try Rito, but better luck next time.
